FacilityName: City of Pharr Water Treatment Plant

_prev_prog_2.Description:
Section 2-Process Safety Information

I.  Introduction

A.  In conjunction with the Process Hazard Assessment (Section 3 of the Program), we have completed a compilation of written process safety information in order to enable our supervisory personnel and our employees who operate the processes to identify and understand the hazards posed by processes involving highly hazardous chemicals.  This safety information will be made readily available to those involved in the processes, and includes but is not limited to: 1. Information pertaining to hazards of the highly hazardous chemicals used in the process, and 2. Information pertaining to the technology of the process.

B.  Further details on chlorine information follows:

Hazard Category                        Chlorine
Toxicity information                     Non-carcinogenic
Permissible exposure limits, ppm  1
Physical data                              Greenish-yellow gas
Corrosivity data                            Most metals corrode 
Reactivity data                             Poison gas
Thermal & Chemical stability data  Stable under normal condition
Hazardous effects of inadverttent    Chemicals to be avoided include
mixing of different materials that     hydrocarbons, ammonia, ether,
could foreseeably occur.                hydrogen,acetylene,turpentine,
                                                    powdered metals and other 
                                                    reducing agents.

1. Hazards of the highly hazardous chemicals used in the process. This information consist of the following:
Process Variables
                                                                Chlorine
Minimum Temperature (F)                                55
Maximum Flowrate (ppd)                                 100
Maximum Inductor Pressure (psi)                     150
Minimum Inductor Pressure (psi)                       30
Vacuum (in Hg)                                                10

C.  We have ascertained that our equipment complies with applicable codes and standards, such as those published by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the American Petroleum Institute, the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, the American National standard Institue, the American Society of Testing and Materials, and the National Fire Protection Association, where they exist; or, with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

II.  Chlorination Process

A.  Process Chemistry 

Chlorine is used to disinfect the water effluent prior to discharging into the water supply system.  Chlorination capacities are generally selected to meet the specific design criteria of the state or other regulatory agencies controlling the water supply system.  In any case, the residual in the effluent is determined by onsite testing.  Ammonia is not added to the water immediately after chlorination at this site.

The general chlorination equations are as follows: Cl2 + H2O<->HOCL+H+Cl

Free residual chlorine is readily obtained with waters of low chlorine demand.  The maintenance of a residual of free chlorine with a Water Treatment plant minimizes the growth of microorganisms and slimes on sand filters and in settling basins.  Free chlorine facilitates the oxidation and removal of inorganic reducing agents and sometimes improves the coagulation behavior of certain waters.
The useful functions of chlorine residuals are: 1.  Control of algae and bacterial aftergrowth, 2.  Reduction of dead end red water problems in the distribution systems; and 3.  Bactericidal protection of drinking water from recontamination.

B.  Maximum Inventory

Chlorine is supplied as liquefied gas under high pressure from one ton container with on additional one ton container online in standby mode.  The maximum inventory for chlorine is eight 1-ton containers or 16,000 pounds.  Equipment manuals, which component specifications, operating parameters, and maintenance procedures, may be found in Appendix B.

C. Process

The chlorination system includes the chlorine supply, chlorinators, and injectors.  The chlorine injector is the controlling component.  The injector is used to create a vacuum that is used to draw the chlorine gas from the chlorine container through the chlorinator, and into the injector.  The chlorinator meters the volume of chlorine solution at the injector, the chlorine dissolves in the injector water supply to form hypochlorous acid.  From the injector, the hypochlorous acid solution flows to the chlorinator (the measuring device) may be held constant or varied in accordance with the flow by changing the degree of vacuum.  Chlorine dioxide is used as a pretreatment.  It is made on an as needed basis with no storage.

D. Consequences of Deviation

If the system is operated beyond the design and operational parameters, the following events may occur. Parameter are Temperature (T), Pressure (P), Flowrate (FR),  Condition are Low (L), High (H).

Parameter    Condition    Effect 
      T                 L          Vapors reliquify & damage equipment
      T                 H          Pressure buildup in system could cause a
                                     release.
      P                 L          Inaccurate metering of chemicals-could 
                                     exceed permit requirements for residuals
                                     concentrations.
      P                 H          Pressure buildup in system could cause 
                                      release
      FR               L          Not meet permit requirements for residual
                                     concentrations.
      FR               H         Could exceed permit requirements for 
                                     residuals concentrations.  

Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) For

RMP REGULATED COMPOUNDS: Chlorine

A copy of the MSDS for all the chemicals at the WTP may be found in the MSDS notebook located in the operation room.

Section 3-Process Hazard Assessment (PHA)

The PHA includes the offsite consequence analysis, PHA, and the 5-year accident history.

I.  OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS (OCA)

A.  The OCA includes a worst case release scenario and an alternative release scenario as defined in 40 CFR Part 68.  A dense gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to estimate the end point distances for both scenarios.  A dense gas model is required since chlorine is heavier than air.  The model's input parameters are summarized below:  

SLAB Input Parameters
                                         Worst Case Scenario   Alter. Scenario
End Point Conc. (mg/l)        0.0087 Cl                    0.0087 Cl
Windspeed (m/s)                1.5                              3
Atmospheric Stability Class    F                             D
Temperature (F)                     104                          104
Humidity (%)                          50                           50
Height of Release (m)              0                             1
Surface Roughness                 1                             1

B.  Worst Case Release Scenario Analysis

1. An analysis of one worst case release scenario was conducted to estimate the greatest distance from a point of release to the end point for chlorine.
2. A worst case release quantity is predetermined as the greatest amount held is a single vessel, taking into account administrative controls that would be released in the event of an accident.  The maximum quantity for chlorine is a 2000 pound (1 ton) instantaneuous release of gas over a 10 minute period.
3. The chlorine containers are in an open area, which does not provide passive mitigation

C.  Alternative Release Scenario Analysis

1. The alternative release scenario was determined from the results of the Process Hazard Review and from the review of historical accident data.
2. The most likely accident to occur is a disconnection of the flex hose that connects the containers to the header line.
3. The release duration was assumed to be 10 minute jet release of gas and liquid.
The results of the air dispersion model are summarized in the table below with the estimated population within the impact area.  The population data was estimated using the Block Uniform Density Group Method in the Landview III computer program.

II.  5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the last 5 years, there have not been accidental release from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

III. PROCESS HAZARD REVIEW

A Process Hazard Review was conducted to identify the following:

* The hazards associated with chlorine processes;
* Opportunities for equipment malfunction or human error that could cause a release;
* Safeguards that will control the hazards or prevent the malfunction or error; and
* Steps to detect or monitor releases.

A What-if and checklist analysis was used to conduct the review.  The review team utilized the What-if Analysis technique to brainstorm the various types of accidents that could occur within the chlorine systems.  Then the team used one or more checklists to help fill in any gaps that were missed.

SLAB OUTPUT PARAMETERS
                                          Worst Case Scenario   Alt. Scenario
Impact Radius (miles)                     4.2                          0.7
Estimated Population                    68,000                      4,500
w/impact area

The What if questions covered the following areas:

* Movement of containers
* Piping from containers to header lines
* Chlorine headers in the Chlorination Area
* Piping from chlorination area to inductors; and
* General areas.

The Checklists covered the following areas:

* Process Safety Information 
* Operating Procedures
* Training
* Incident Investigation
* Emergency Planning & Response 
* Compliance Audits

The results of the review may be seen in the Executive Summary.

Section 4-OPERATING AND MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES

I. OPERATING PROCEDURES

A. The City of Pharr developed and implemented written standard operating procedures (SOPs) that are consistent with the process safety information (section 2).  Those procedures provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in the chlorine system consistent with the process safely information.  They address the following:

1. The steps for each operating phase:
    a. Initial startup
    b. Normal operation 
    c. Normal shutdown

2. Operating limits:
    a. Consequences of deviation
    b. Steps required to correct and/or avoid deviation 
    c. Equipment

B. Copies of the operating procedures are readily accessible in office to employees who work in or maintain the chlorine systems.

C. The operating procedures are reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology, and equipment; changes to facilities.

II.  MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES

A.  The City of Pharr developed and implented written maintenance procedures that are consistent with the Process Safety Information (section 2).  Those procedures are used to maintain the on-going mechanical integrity of the chlorine process equipment.

B. The City of Pharr trained all present employees and will train future employees involved in maintaining the on-going mechanical integrity of the chlorine process equipment.  To ensure that those employees can perform the job tasks in a safe manner, each employee is trained in the hazards of the process, how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks.

C. The City of Pharr has a SOP in place that ensures that each contract maintenance employee is trained to perform the maintenance procedures developed.

D. The City of Pharr performs rountine inspections and tests on chlorine process equipment.  Inspecting and testing procedures follow recognized and generally accepted good engineering pracitces.  The frequency of the inspections and tests of chlorine process equipment are consistent with applicable manufacturer's recommendations, industry standards or codes, good engineering practices, and prior operating experience.

The City of Pharr makes an annual certification that those operating & maintenance procedures are both current and accurate.  The SOP covered under this Plan may be found in Appendix E.

SECTION 5-TRAINING

A. INITIAL TRAINING

Except as specified in Part B (below) each employee presently involved in a process, and each employee before working in a newly assigned process,is trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures as specified in Section 4.  The training will include emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, procedures, and safe practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.

B. REFRESHER&SUPPLEMENTAL TRAINING FOR OPERATIONS

Refresher and supplemental training is provided to each employee in operating a process at least every three years (and more often if necessary) in order to assure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process.

C. REFRESHER&SUPPLEMENTAL TRAINING FOR EMERGENCY

Refresher and supplemental training is provided to each employee involved in emergency response on an annual basis (and more often if necessary)in order to assure that the employee understands and adheres to the current emergency response procedures.

D. TRAINING DOCUMENTATION

The City of Pharr's training program ensures that each such employee has received, successfully completed, and understood such training.  Training documentation contains, as a minimum, the following information and may be found in Appendix F.

The identity of the employee
The date of training and completion 
If available certification of completion

E. TRAINING COURSE

During each training session, each student is provided (if available) a handout for future reference.  The handout (if available) provides technical and regulatory information specific to the particular course, as well as information on good practices.

The training is conducted using City of Pharr personal protective equipment (PPE), including self contained breathing apparatus (SCBA's) and when available, with employees personally assigned respirators.  This allows students to be trained on the equipment they may actually use.

Upon successful completion of the course, each participant receives a certificate of completion for this training.  The certificate documents successful completion of the course.

It includes the employee's name, date of completion, subject matter, and the instructor's name.

SECTION 6-COMPLIANCE AUDITS

A. The City of Pharr WTP process safety management system will be regularly evaluated in order to:

1. Measure its effectiveness
2. Direct our attention to potential weakness in the system
3. Verify that the procedures & practices that we have developed under EPA standard are adequate
4. Assure that all required procedures & practices are being followed.

B. The evaluation will be conducted at least every three years.

C. It will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.

D. The finding of the audit will be developed into a report.

E. The audit team will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the finding of the compliance audit, and will document that deficiencies have been corrected.

F.  The two most recent compliane audit reports will be retained in the RMP and may be found in Appendix G.

SECTION 7-INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

A. All incidents will be investigated that have either resulted in a catastrophic release of a highly hazardous chemical in the workplace, or could have reasonably resulted in a release.

B. Each such incident investigation will be initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following the incident.

C. An incident investigation team will be established to thoroughly investigate and analyze each such incident.  The membership of the investigation team will include at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience.

D. The investigation team must prepare a report at the conclusion of each investigation which includes at a minimum: date of incident, date of investigation began, a description of the incident, the factors that contributed to the incident, and any recommendations for future prevention/mitigation resulting from the investigation.

E. The City of Pharr has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report's finding and recommendations.  All corrective actions and resolutions that are taken in response shall be documented.

F. The report of the investigation team will be reviewed with all affected personnel, whose job tasks are relevent to the incident findings, including conract employees.

G. All incident investigation reports shall be retained for five years and may be found in Appendix H.

SECTION 8-EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

EMERGENCY CONTACT NUMBERS

DIAL 911 for all emergencies and request assistance from the fire department.  The dispatcher will then notify the fire department and police.  If a person needs medical attention, request emergency medical treatment personnel.  Then call one of the LEPC coordinators listed below.

WTP LEPC Numbers-Charlie Montgomery, Emergency Mgr Coordinator, (956)318-2600(work) or 911(24 hrs).

PHARR FIRE DEPARTMENT
Calling 911 would contacted them.  The FD is the first responder to an emergency.

OUTSIDE SERVICES (to be contacted only in event of a RQ release)
National Repsonse Center 1-800-424-8802
CHEMTREC  1-800-424-9300

Regulated Substance-chlorine, Reportable Quantity (RQ)- 10 lbs

I. PURPOSE AND SCOPE

The City of Pharr has developed this written Emergency Repsonse Plan for the WTP to provide guidance for responding to accidental releases of chlorine. The plan was developed in accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68, Subpart E. Emergency response procedures are necessary because accidents can occur, even with the best safety programs in place. Emergency reponse is to be undertaken to reduce the severity of a release and protect employees, emergency responders, and the public from harmful exposure to chlorine.

A. APPPLICATION

The WTP is subject to the Clean Air Act's RMP regulations, which require emergency response actions including public notification, emergency training to respond to an offsite release of chlorine. The EPA risk management regulations require that at a minimum, plans must be developed for notifying offsite responders and providing first aid(for facilities that will not respond with its employees); for community notification and coordination with the community response plan; for using, maintaining, and testing emergency response systems and equipment; and employee training.

The ERP shall include the following elements:

* Emergency escape procedures & escape route assignments
* Procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate
* Procedures to account for all employees after emergency evacuation has been completed
* Rescue & medical duties for those employees who are to perform them
* Preferred means of reporting fires & other emegencies
* Names & regular job titles of persons or departments who can be contacted for further information of duties under the plan
* An emergency alarm system shall be established
* The types of evacuation to be used in emergency circumstances shall be established in the emergency plan
* Training of employees to assist in the safe and orderly emergency evacuation of employees.

The ERP developed herein shall be coordinated with the community emergency response plan developed under 42 USC 11003.  Upon request by the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) or emergency reponse officials, WTP shall promptly provide to the local emergency response officials, information necessary for developing and implementing the community response plan.

B. EXEMPTIONS

The contents of this emergency response program apply to the entire WTP, although it is primarily intended to address a release of chlorine the WTP's chlorination processes.  Chlorine is the only regulated substance in the water treatment process that is present above threshold quantities.

This emergency reponse program does not include responses to incidental releases of regulated substances, including chlorine, where the substances can be "absorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area.

II. REFERENCES

The listing is not intended to be exhaustive and the reader is referred to 40 CFR 68 and 29 CFR 1910 for a more complete regulatory listing.

A. REGULATORY
    1. 29CFR1910.38(a)-OSHA Emergency Action Plan Regulation
    2. 29CFR1910.120-OSHA Hazwoper Regulation
    3. 29CFR1910.1200-OSHA Hazard Communication
    4. Clean Air Act of 1990, Section 112(r)
    5. 40CFR68-RMP
    6. 42USC11003-Superfund Amendments&Reauthorization Act of 
        1986, Title III, Emergency Planning&Community Right toKnow

B. Documents
    1. Risk Management Program for the WTP
    2. The Chlorine Manual-The Chlorine Institute

III. REPORTING

A. PROCEDURES

In the event that there is a fire or a release of chlorine, the person(s) discovering the fire or release is to immediately report the incident to the Operation Manager or person designated in his palce.  If the emergency is critical call 911 before calling the Operation Manager.  The Operation Manager will call the LEPC if necessary and determine if a reportable quantity (RQ) release has occurred.  The LEPC will notify other appropriate contacts, as they deem necessary: 

Information to be reported to emergency responders should include the following (upon calling 911): chemical released, estimated quantity released, time and duration of the release, evacuation and/or sheltering plans, name and telephone number of the person(s) to be contacted for further information.

IV. EMERGENCY EVACUATION

A. EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEM

If a release of chlorine occurs, the chlorine sensor will sound an audible alarm and activate the strobe light on top of the building.  A signal is also sent to the main building.  THERE ARE NO OTHER AUDIBLE OR VISUAL ALARMS AT THE PLANT THAT WILL SIGNAL THAT A CHLORINE RELEASE HAS OCCURRED.

A windsock, located close to the chlorine area, indicates wind direction.  All employees should note the wind direction and move up-wind or crosswind to a release of chlorine.

B. TYPES OF EVACUATION

In the event of a release, employees will either be required to evacuate the plant or be sheltered in place.  This will be dependent upon wind direction, severity of the release, and in what part of the plant the release has occurred.

C. EMERGENCY EVACUATION AND SHELTERING

In the event of an emergency, the Operation Manager or his designee will determine if employees will need to evacuate the plant or be sheltered in place.  If evacuation is necessary, employees will be directed to report to one of the three following fence lines: North, East or West
Evacuation to these locations will be dependent upon wind direction and where a release has occurred. Evacuation routes to these locations have been posted at locations throughout the plant.  Employees will not be allowed to return to the plant until they have been directed to do so by the Operations Manager or one of his designates.

If sheltering in place is necessary, employees will be directed to report to the following location: Operation Building

Employees are to remain in the Operation Building until emgency response crew have determined it is safe to leave.

D. COMMUNICATION

Directions to either evacuate the plant or move to the designated sheltering in place location will be broadcast by two-way radio.

E. ACCOUNTING FOR EMPLOYEES

If evacuation from the plant or sheltering in place becomes necessary, the Operation Manager will account for employees by making a head count from the plant's employee work list and contractor list.

F. CRITICAL PLANT OPERATIONS PROCEDURES

Prior to evacuation from the plantand/or sheltering in place, the chief plant operator and plant operator will each don appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) and self contained breathing apparatus(SCBA) as necessary. The Chief Plant Operator and Plant Operator willshut down system as necessary.

If evacuation of the plant has been ordered, above personnel will report to the designated evacuation location once emergency shutdown has been completed.  If sheltering in place has been ordered, the above personnel will remain in operations.

G. OFF-SITE EMERGENCY RESPONSE

In the event that a release of chlorine threatens or actually moves off-site, the fire department will be responsible for communicating and notifying affected off-site populations about what actions to take.

V. RESCUE AND MEDICAL DUTIES

A. EMERGENCY RESPONSE

The WTP has elected to be a non-responding facility.  Therefore, trained personnel with the Fire Department or EMS will perform any rescue or medical duties.

Another WTP employee must accompany any plant employee that is sent to the hospital during an emergency.  If possible an MSDS or a copy of medical procedures for treament of exposure to chlorine should accompany the injured employee to the hospital.  This will be helpful to medical personnel who will treat the injured employee(s).

VI. TRAINING

A. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Each WTP employee should receive orientation training regarding the facility's emergency reponse program.  Refresher training should be presented at least annually and at a minumum cover the following elements: discussion of the ERP, roles and reponsibilities of each employee, checklist for action to be taken, telephone list updates, first aid and cpr training, chlorine hazards, do's and don'ts during an emergency, emergency response and safety equipment, diagram showing evacuation routes and sheltering location(s).

WTP personnel will perform periodic drills to test the participant's reactions and effectiveness in emplementing the ERP. Full scale emergency drills will be conducted at discretion of the Fire Dept.  These drills will include involvement of outside emergency response crews, plant personnel and management. Periodic in plant drills will also be conducted using different release events, and involve as many plant perosnnel as possible.

VII. PLAN REVIEW AND MODIFICATION 

The ERP will be reviewed annually or when a significant process and safety change takes place, also the plan will modified as needed.

VIII. DOCUMENTATION

Copies of the following documents will be maintained with RMP: incident reports, incident training reports, training records, and audit results

IX. RECEPTORS

Landview III was used to identify the public and environmental receptors.  They are:

1. Worst Case Scenario-Chlorine within 4.2 miles

Schools: Navarro, Roosevelt, Eli Whitney, Doedyns, Franklin, Buell, Palmer ELementary, Pharr Elementary, Napper, Ford, PSJA High School, Liberty Middle, Buckner, Austin, Carnahan, Sorensen.

2. Alternative Case Scenario-Chlorine within 0.7 miles

Schools: Liberty Middle, Pharr Elementary, Palmer Elementary, PSJA High School.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
SECTION 1

We have adopted this Program in order to implement 40C.F.R. 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This program will help prevent the occurence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies

The City of Pharr believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities (another entity has agreed in advance to respond to the release). This facility is a non-responding facility.  The City of Pharr Fire Department is the first responder.

The emergency response program does not include responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances, including chlorine, where the substances can be "adsorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area.

The City of Pharr has taken steps to train the operators and supervisors to be knowledge in the emergency response program.  The training includes classroom and hands on training on the proper use of emergency response equipment and procedures.  Above all, all employees know where the phone numbers of the first responders are located should a release occur.

Stationary Source & Regulated Substances

The Water Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine for disinfection.  The maximum inventory and threshold quatity for Chlorine is: Maximum Inventory (lbs) 16,000             Threshold Quantity (lbs) 2,500.

Offsite Consequence Analysis

The offsite consequence analysis includes a worst case release scenario and an alternati

ve release scenario as defined in 40 C.F.R. 68.  A dense gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios.  A dense gas model is required since chlorine is heavier than air.  The model's input parameters are summarized:   SLAB Input Parameters
                                                            Worst Case Scenario                            Alternative Scenario
Windspeed (m/s)                                                1.5                                                           3
Atmospheric Stability Class                                  F                                                            D
Temperature (F)                                                  104                                                        104
Humidity (%)                                                         50                                                          50
Height of Release (m)                                            0                                                             0
Surface Roughness                                               1                                                            1
                                                                       Chlorine                                                  Chlorine
End Points                                                         0.0087                                                  0.0087

The results of the air dispersion model are summarized in the table below along with the estimated population within the impact area.  The population was estimated using the Block Uniform Density Group Method in Landview III, which uses the 1990 US Census to estimate population. 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program
                                                                                  SLAB Output Parameters
                                                             Worst Case Scenario                                     Alt

ernative Scenario
Impact Radius (miles)                                        4.2                                                                  0.7
Estimated Population with Impact Area             68,000                                                          4,500

The City of Pharr has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases.  This Program includes: safety information on the covered chemicals, hazards reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.

Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The city will address the recommendation of the process hazards assessment for all areas of the prevention program and the emergency response program.

The executive summary was copied from the June 15, 1999 City of Pharr Water Treament Plant RMP submitted by Enercon Services Inc to EPA.  The city continues to strive in following the RMP and RMP was revised on May 20, 2009.

Hazard Review Results WTP May 20, 1999/2004/2009

1.Process Safety Information, Questions-Are MSDS available?, Reason-Need Chemical data, consequences-Injury may occur from mishandling chemical., Recommendation-Continue availability of MSDS to all employees.

2. Operating Procedures (OP), Questions-Are there written SOP that cover regulated chemicals?, Reason-to make sure activity is performed in a safe manner., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur from not following SOPs., Recommendations-Revise SOP need to be reviewed and updated as needed.

3. OP, Questions-Are the procedures reviewed annually for accuracy?, Reason-Keep up with process changes., consequence-Using ou

tdated SOPs may result in injury or equipment damage. Recommendations-All SOPs need to be updated as needed.

4. OP, Questions-Does each procedures include the date and authorization signatures of last review?, Reason-Keeps less knowledgeable people from creating SOPs., Consequence-using unapproved SOPs may result in injury or equipment damage., Recommendations-All SOPs need to include number, authorization date and signature, and last date reviewed.

5. Contractor Safety, Question-Are contractors aware of hazards and safety procedures?, Reason-Protect contractors from hazards, consequences-Contractor may get hurt and cause legal problems., Recommendations-All employees have to make sure that contractors are aware of the hazards and emergency proceudres.

6. Training, Question-Is refresher training provided?, Reason-Keep employees up-to date, Consequence Injury or equipment damage may occur if employee forgets traing., Recommedations-Document all training and place records in RMP.

7.Training, Question-Are all personnel informed of any procedures prior to implementation?, Reason-Employee may attempt to use old procedure., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur if old procedure is implemented., Recommendation-Verify all employees understand new procedures and document in RMP.

8. Training, Is all training documented?, Reason-Make sure all employees are properly trained., Consequence-Management cannot assume everyone has been trained without some type of documentation procedures., Recommendation-Document all training in the RMP including informal training and formal training sessions.

9. Incident Investigation (II), Question-Are written reports prepared for each incident at the conclusion of the investigation?, Reason-Written reports will be used to determine there is an incident pattern with an employee or a piece of equipment., Consequence-Details are forgotten using verbal reports., Recommendation-Incident reports should be placed in the RMP.

10. II, Qu

estion-Has a system been established to determine and resolve the appropriate response to the incident report's finding?, Reason-Reduce the possibility of a similar incident from occurring., Consequence-Incidents can become rountine if not resolved in a timely manner., Recommendations-Incident reports should include a section to document that the recommendations have been followed.

11. Emergency Response (ER), Questions-Are there suitable methods of notifying personnel of emergencies?, Reason-All employees and contractors need to be informed on when emergencies occur., Consequence-Injuries may occur if employees are not notified of emergencies., Recommendations-Continue monthly testing of leak detectors and alarms for chlorine leaks. Verify that audio and visual methods of notifying all employees on site are sufficient-hand held radios, monitor sirens, beacon, etc.

12. ER, Questions-Do all employees and contractors know the evacuation routes and gather points?, Resaon-Rast egress from an area nad headcount are important during emergencies., Consequence-All personnel may not be accounted for if they do not know where to check in., Recommendations-Revise the ERPs to include evacuation routes and primary and secondary gathering points for employees and contractors. Designate a sheltering in place location at the facility.

13. ER, Question-Do all employees know the proper PPE for each activity?, Reason-Different activities require different levels of PPE., Consequence-Injuries may occur if employees are not properly protected., Recommendations-Containter changeout-shield,respirator,PVC,rainsuit, and chemical resistant gloves. The change out team should consist of 2 trained and outfitted people. Release repair/invetigation chemical resistant suit, SCBA, chemical resistant gloves, rubber boots. The response team should consist of two trained and outfitted people and a backup team similarly dressed out.

14. Compliance Audits, Questions-Are compliance audits performed o

n a rountinebasis? Reason-Personnel and equipment may change over time.  Consequence-Outdated SOPs may lead to injury or equipment damage. Recommendation-Conduct compliance audits every year and document in RMP.

15. Compliance Audits, Questions-Has a system been established to determine and resolve the appropriate response to the compliance audit's findings?, Reason-make sure SOPs are being followed and to verify SOPs are up-to-date., Consequence-Outdated SOPs may lead to injury or equipment damage., Recommendation- compliance audits should include a recommendation section and a section to document that the recommendation have been followed.

16. Handling 1-ton container of chlorine, Question-What if the container is dropped from the lifting apparatus?, Reason-Do employees know proper lifting techniques and what to do if container is dropped?, Consequence-A dropped container could break open and cause a major release., Recommendations-Revise SOPs to include inspections of lifting equipment, proper lifting techniques, and response procedures if a containter is dropped.

17. Handling 1-ton container of chlorine, Question-Are the wheels chocked during unloading/laoding process?, Reason-Truck could start rolling and cause the container to drop., consequence-A dropped container could break open and cause a major release., Recommendation-Revise SOP to include chocking truck wheels and send a copy to the SOP to chemical vendor.

18. Storage of 1-ton containers of chlorine., Question-Are the container storage cradles adequate for intended purpose?, Reason-Inadequate cradles could allow containers to roll off storage platform., Consequence-Container could be damaged on impact and cause a release., Recommendations-Revise SOP to include inspections of container cradles and replace damaged cradles.  Install container cradles to prevent containers from moving during the loading/unloading process.

19. Handling 1-ton containers of chlorine, Question-What if the containers are no

t empty when removed from service?, Reason-Gases could still escape during handling., Consequences-Injury may occur if perosnnel think the containers are empty and get careless., Recommendations-Revise SOPs and training to emphasize the need to handle the containers as if they are full at all times.

20. Handling 1-ton containers of chlorine, Question- What if automatic swithover system fails?, Reason-Residual will decrease to zero., consequence-Residual discharge limits will not be met., Recommendations- Evaluate if a rotometer is necessary on each of the supply lines for visual indication of which tank is online.  Evaluate if flow sensors are necessary in the system and have them alarm the operators station.

21. Handling 1-ton containers of chlorine, Questions-What if the incorrect chemicals are delivered?, Reason-Purchase requisition may not have been properly placed or filled., Consequence-Residual discharge limits may not be met., Recommendation-Revise SOPs and training to include chemical identification and shipment refusals.

22. Handling 1-ton container of chlorine, Questions-What if the containers are not in good condition?, Reason-Container integrity may be at question., Consequence-Damaged containers are more likely to have a release., Recommendation-Revise SOPs and training to include chemical shipment inspections before containers are unloaded and shipment refusals.

23. Equipemt (EQ), Questions-What if flexhoses rupture while connected online?, Reason-Flexhoses not replaced during routine maintenance., Consequence-The entine content of the container could escape before the leak is detected., Recommendations- Document that flexhoses are replaced following manufacturers schedule. Document that the chlorine sensor at the container properly functions.

24. EQ, Questions-What if flexhose connections open or leak when pressure is applied?, Reason-Incorrectly installed when container where changed. Threaded fitting worn out., Consequence-The entire contents

of the container could escape before the leak is detected., Recommendations-Document that flexhoses are replaced following manufacturers schedule. Document that chlorine sensors around tanks properly function. Reinforce the need to check for leaks after installing new containers or if there is a suspected leak.

25. EQ, Question-What if something is dropped onto container or equipment?, Reason-Tools could be dropped during maintenance activities around containers., Consequence-The containers and/or equipment could be damaged and cause a leak., Recommendations-Revise SOPs to include procedures of checking all equipment if something is dropped on the containers and/orequipment.  Also revise the SOP to state the operator will increase frequency of daily inspections to verify that the equipment does not start leaking.

26. EQ, Questions-What if liquid chlorine is withdrawn through the vapor lines?, Reason-There is failure of the regulator. Consequence-EQ damage and potential for release., Recommendation-Revise traiing procedures to include equipment troubleshooting.

27. EQ, Questions-What if cylinder valve cannot be closed during an emergency?, Reason-corrosion could keep valve from being closed., Consequence-Containter contents could escape before emergency repairs could be completed., Recommendation-If possible remove leaking container to a safer area. If possible, roll container over so that the leaking valve is positioned on the top of the tank.

28. EQ, Questions-Do the operators know how to use the B kits and the limitations of the kits?, Reason-Operators may not have been trained on the use of B kits., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur if repair kits are improperly used., Recommedation-Revise training SOPs to include B kits use and limitations

29. EQ, Question-What if liquid is trapped between two valves and the temperature rises?, Reason-Operators improperly shut down the supply system., Consequence-The vaporized liquid will expand and could cau

se the line to rupture and cause a release. Recommendation-Revise SOPs to include proper system shutdown. Evaluate if expansion chambers are necessary between two valves.

30. EQ, Questions-What if there is a fire near the containers?, Reason-Nearby grass could catch fire. Electrical panels could catch on fire., Consequences-Pressure within containers could increase to a point where plugs rupture causing a release., Recommendation-Revise SOPs to include proper use of fire extinguishers. Make sure there are the proper types of fire extinquishers in the area. If possible move containers out of the area.

31. EQ, Question-What if operator leaves valve open and disconnects the flexhose?, Reason-Improper training for operators. Consequence-Significant release could occur before valve could be closed.  Recommendations-Document that all operators are properly trained in all procedures.

32. EQ, Question-What if water enters the system?, Reason-Ejector fails to create a vacuum., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur if water enters the system. Water and chlorine gas creates a very corrisive environment that can damage equipment. Recommedation-Document that rountine maintenance includes ejector system.

33. Chlorination System (CS), Question-What if the pressure builds up on the system?, Reason-Ambient temperature increases. Gas flow inhibited., Consequences- Excess pressure could cause a release., Recommendations-Make sure detection systems are in working order.

34. CS, Questions-What if a valve leaks?, Reason-Inadequate preventive maintenance. Improperly installed valve., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may result due to the release., Recommendation-Document on a regular basis that the sensors are properly operating.  Revise SOPs to include proper valve installation and repair procedures.

35. CS, Question-What if there is inadequate flow in the gas line?, Reason-clogged filter., Consequence-Discharge limits for chlorine may not be met., Recommendation-C

hange filters based on manufacturer recommendations or as needed.  Evaluate if pressure switches are necessary to indicate chlorine flow failure.

36. CS, Question-What if the vacuum regulator valve fails?, Reason-Inadequate preventive maintenance. Equipment failure., Consequence-Gas will flow out of the vent tubes on the vacuum regulator., Recommendation-Perform rountine maintenance based on manufacturer recommendation or as needed.

37. CS, Question-What if there is liquid carryover to vacuum regulating valve?, Reason-If heaters fail., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur., Recommendations-Revise SOPs to include heater inspection.  Document that rountine maintenance is being performed on all equipment following manufacturer schedule and procedures.

38. CS, Question-What if there are leaks in the chlorinator?, Reason-Equipment failure, inadequate preventive maintenance, equipment improperly installed., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur due to release., Recommendations-Document that chlorine sensors around the tanks properly function., Review preventive maintenance procedures and training.

39. CS, Question-What if there is a rupture of the pipe from the chlorinator to inductor?, Reason-Equipment failure., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur due to release. Discharge limits may not be met., Recommendation-Evaluate if pressure switches are necessary on lines. Document that chlorine sensor properly functions. Increase frequency of effluent testing.

40. CS, Question-What if water pump is not working?, Reason-Power failure. Equipment failure., consequence-Chlorination process is designed to shut down at the loss of vacuum., Recommendations-Verify backup generators are maintained and operational during power failure.  Operators should inspect chlorination process during water pump failure to verify equipment is shut down and there are no signs of releases.

41. General (G), Question-What if there is a power failure?, Reason-Sever

e weather. Utility problems., Consequence-Storage capacity could be exceeded., Recommendation-Verify backup generators and maintained and operational during power failure.

42. G, Question-What if a release occurs during maintenance?, Operators not following proper SOPs., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may result due to release., Recommendation-review operating and maintenance procedures. Document training.

43. G, Question-What if a release is not detected?, Reason-Sensors not functioning., Consequences-A major release could occur if the release was not detected in a reasonable time., Recommendations-Document that all chlorine sensors properly function.

44. G, Question-What if ambient temperatureis too high?, Reason-Ambient temperature in the summer can exceed 100 F., Consequence-Pressure within containers may increase and cause a release., Recommendation-Keep containers out of direct sunlight. Increase operator inspection round during the summer months.

45. G, Question-What if the ambient temperature is too low?, Reason-Ambient temperature in winter can drop below 32 F., Consequences-Gases may reliquify and damage equipment., Recommendation Verify that the temperature within chlorine container is maintained above 55 F.

46. G, Question-What if there is severe weather?, Reason-Area is prone to severe weather., Consequences-Injury of equipment damage may result due to severe weather., Recommedations-Revise SOPs to include severe weather procedures and document training.
